title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The camera pans across a nicely appointed study, rests a bit, and "SOUTH PARK classics" appears on screen as a classical piece plays

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Aaah.  Dickens. The imagery of cobblestone streets, cragging London buildings, and nutmeg-filled Yorkshire puddings. Hello, I'm a British person. For years now, the character Pip has been featured prominently in the American show, South Park. However, many Americans don't realize where Pip came from. He's the prowling little adorable Englishman from Charles Dickens' timeless classic, "Great Expectations"  And so tonight, the makers of South Park have agreed to take a break from their regular show, and instead present the prestigious Dickens tale in its entirety from beginning to end. Indeed, after watching this show, you'll know the timeless classic as if you'd... read the Cliff Notes themselves. Our story is set in England, in the small town of Drop-A-Chair-Upon-Top-Snot, where a young blond-haired boy named Pip was on his way to see his parents.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Drop-A-Chair-Upon-Top-Snot, day. Pip leaves the town, crosses an open field, enters an enclosed lot and stops right in front of the camera

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: 'Ello Mom. 'Ello Dad. It certainly is nice to see you again.  Don't worry. Sister is still taking very good care of me. She just loves to smack me in the face and tell me I'm worthless. O, we have such fun together.  But it's getting dark, Mom and Dad. I'll see you again soon.  Wa-a-ah!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Wha' are you doin' 'ere, you little whippersham!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, hello. Why, you look like an escaped convict. Did we breaky-wakys out of prison?  Oh dear! But you're shackled. Here, let me help you.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Wha' are you doin' wit' those?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I'm an apprentice blacksmith.  There you are.  And here's a sandwich. You must be starving!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Here. W-why are you easy to help me?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, it's not for me to judge you, sir. We are all the same.  Don't quite outmart this thing, I'm afraid.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Pip, where 'ave you been?!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Waaah!  Lovely day, isn't it?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: What the hell's lovely about it?!  Joe, teach this boy some bloody cynicsim!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I don't know about that. I just thought I'd keep to me blacksmithing.  Ey, look! I've made me a metal fire poker.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: A lot of bloody good a fire poker's gonna do while I'm starvin' to death! Why don't you make us some bloody food to eat!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Alright. Look 'ere, I made me a metal orange.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: STOP your metal orange, you bastard! You never want a tablespoon of nigh'ingale droppin's, you me'al-poundin' fairy! And you! Why don't you ge' a job?! You're eight years old now!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, lookie heeah!  I've gone and made a metal newspaper!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Shut up, you silly lip! What are we supposed to do with a metal newspaper?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, for starters we can look in the want ads and see if we can find Pip a job. Ohhh, lookie here! Young man wanted for paid position!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Where?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Where?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: "Havesham residence seeks young boy to play with lonely daughter. Will pay up to..." TWENTY QUID A DAY??

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: That's a lot of  money-loney.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: You can keep a little girl company for 20 quid a day, Pip. And Old Mrs. Havesham is the wealthiest woman in the town.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Havesham Residence is shown from the gates, next day.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The South Park Classics study. The British is seated in an armchair reading a book

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, the very next day, Pip went to Old Ms. Havesham's house to inquire about the job.  and it was there that he met the girl of his dreams.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: A girl approached the gate at the Havesham Residence. She's got flowing blonde hair and a bowler for a hat

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Who are you?!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: ...I've come to answer the want ad.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Is that so, you smelly little bastard?!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: What??

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: This way, you pathetic squirt of vaginal discharge!  This way, you beef-witted shriveled-up monkey's penis.  Up here, you gamy mass of baby vomit!  In here.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Eho. After you, miss.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I'm not going in there, you stupid puddle of a homeless man urine!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Havesham Estate, upstairs. Pip enters a grand dining room in which everything is covered, and has been for a long time. He scans the room until a voice gets his attention.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Who is that?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I've come to answer the want ad, ma'am.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Come closer. Look at me.  Does it frighten you to look upon a woman who has not seen the sun in over 20 years?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, no, no! You you sort of look upon one when you have not seen the sun for over 20 years quite a lot these... days.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I sometimes have sick fancies.  And I have a fancy I should like to see someone play. So, play. Play.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Um.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Estella, play with this boy.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: With HIM?  But he's just a commoner!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: But, you can break his heart.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: ...Alright, boy, let us play.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Righty-o. What are we going to play?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: We're going to play a little game called, "Smack the Blond Boy In the Head With a Large Log."

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, yes! My sister and I play that game at home all the time!  Who will go first?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, you stupid pathetic boy!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: What do you think of her?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, uh... I think she's very pretty.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Hm-m-m. What else?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I think she's rather insulting.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Hm, you quite fancy her, don't you? Come back again next week. We shall "play" some more.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The blacksmith's house, night. Pip returns to his sister's place and gets ready to bed for the night. He falls asleep

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: That night, Pip spent all his sleeping hours unable to get Estella's beautiful face out of his mind.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Stop dreaming about me, you slow-witted rectal belch!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Day after day Pip visited Estella. Sometimes they would play, sometimes they would talk. But every single day Pip's love for Estella grew.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Havesham Estate, garden, day. Estella is whacking Pip over the head with her log. Twice she does it, then tries a third time, but can't

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Don't you wanna play anymore?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Boy, do you still think I'm pretty?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oho. Well, yes, miss.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: And, do you still think I'm insulting?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, um, not so much as before.  Ow!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I hate you! You're an oozing, painful hemorrhoid that belches pus!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, dear.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: You may kiss me if you like.  Come. Let us walk in the daisy garden.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, what fun it is to splash about in the fountain!  You there, the prowling little boy! I bet you can't jump on my back!  Go on, then. Try and jump on my back!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Who is that?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Just another playmate hired to amuse me. You didn't think you were the only one, did you?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh I... rather thought I was.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, you silly small-testicled boy. Come, let us walk through the rose garden.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Havesham Estate, exterior. The camera looks at the second floor, focusing on Ms. Havesham

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes, good. She will break his pathetic heart into a million pieces.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The South Park Classics study. The British Person resumes narrating

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, what a spot poor Pip was in. He was hired to be the friend of the very harsh and beautiful Estella. And although she treated him like dirt, or perhaps because she treated him like dirt, Pip found himself more in love with the little girl each and every day.  Oh, bless him! Isn't he lovely??  But, isn't it sad? Because Pip knew that someone as sophisticated and as wealthy as Estella could never love him, for he was just a simple blacksmith's apprentice.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The blacksmith's house, night. Joe is working on another creation. Pip watches

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: And so you bang on this side, and bang on that side, and there you have it. Your very own metal fuzzy dice.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes. I see.  Hoh, lovely.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Eeyyyy, what's all this, Pip?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Joe, do you know anything about girls?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Sure! They're those things with vaginas in them.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: But, do you anything about them? About how they work.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, I don't know about that. I just like to keep to me blacksmithin'.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Do you think that a girl who is rich and educated would ever want to be with a blacksmith?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh. D'ooooh. No, I don't think so, Pip. Who could that be?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Joe, the blacksmith?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The same.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I'm a lawyer from London in search of a young lad named Pip.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I'm Pip, sir.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Mr. Blacksmith, I've been sent here to offer you a reasonable sum of money in exchange for your apprentice.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, well, uh Pip's not for sale, sir.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I have a client who wishes to give this bright child a future. Anything he desires. Do you still object?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Heaven forbid I should stand in the way of Pip's future, but-

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: He will one day inherit a handsome property. But the owner of that property wants him first to travel to London and learn to be a gentleman.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: That's great news!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: There's only one condition, Pip. Your benefactor wishes to remain anonymous

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oho. But it must be Ms. Havesham!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: OH OH! If you have any suspicion of who that person might be, you are to keep it in your own breast. Understood?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes sir.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Then you will go to London in a week's time.  Here's 20 sterling. Well, blacksmith, you look stunned.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I am, sir.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Then I should take my leave.  Good evening, gentlemen, and we shall see you in London next week, Pip.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Good-bye, sir.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Pip!  A young gentleman! Of great expectations!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: London, a foggy night. Big Ben peals in the background. The camera pans down from the skyline to a horse-drawn carriage, which comes to a stop. Pip and the lawyer get out

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: You shall stay here with your roommate, Mr. Pocket. He is a distinguished young lad who will help you on your way to being a gentleman. I trust you see no problem with this?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: None, sir.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I should think not.  On up, then, and prepare for school on the morrow.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Dormitory. Pip walks down the hall and finds a door with his name under that of Mr. Pocket. He is about to knock when a boy opens the door

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Mr. Pip?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Mr. Pocket?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Pray, come in!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Thank you kindly. You do look rather familiar

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: As do you. Perhaps we've seen each other before. As to our lodging, it's not by any means splendid. This is our sitting room - just chairs and tables and carpet and so forth.  This is my little room - rather musty, and this is your bedroom.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: My, how lovely.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, what a gay time we shall have, and I do mean gay as in festive, not as in penetration of the bum. Oh, but dear me! I beg your pardon! You're holding your bags all this time! Pray, let me take them!  I'm quite ashamed!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh it's... quite alright.  Lord bless me! Why, you're the pale young man I saw at Ms. Havesham's house!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Why, yes of course! You're the prowling little boy! Boy, what a smashing coincidence!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Perhaps, but perhaps not. Ms. Havesham is very generous indeed.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: That old biddy? Oh, I assure you, I have nothing to do with her anymore. She's absolutely mad!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, what do you mean?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, don't you know about Ms. Havesham's melancholy past? Dear me, it's quite a story, and should be discussed over dinner. Come!  Right, time for a smashing meal and the story of Ms. Havesham.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Pocket, may I ask you a favor? I am desperately trying to become a gentleman! For the love of a certain girl. So, will you please tell me if I do something wrong at the table?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: You'll do fine, dear fellow, just fine. Now on to Ms. Havesham: She was raised by a wealthy father and grew up to be a somewhat of a spoiled brat.  And now I might mention, Pip, that in London it is not the custom to put the knife in the mouth.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Hoh, dear, I'm terribly sorry!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Not at all, I'm sure.  Anyway, Ms. Havesham grew up to be a lovely young lady, and soon a man came along, which gets me to the cruel part of the story, merely breaking off, Pip , to remark that a dinner napkin should never be placed into the tumbler.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Sorry! Sorry!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Not at all, I'm sure.  So this man pursued Ms. Havesham closely and professed to be devoted to her. She passionately loved him back. The marriage day was fixed, the wedding dress was bought, the wedding guests were all invited, and finally the day came. But not the groom.  And I break from the tale now only to mention that one should never pass gas at the dinner table!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh. Excuse me.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Not at all, I'm sure. So the groom never showed. He simply wrote a letter, a letter that Ms. Havesham received 20 minutes before the wedding.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: At half nine, the time when she stopped all the clocks in the house.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: But afterward she laid waste to the entire house, as you have seen it, and has never since looked upon the light of day. And the story ends, Pip, with me suggesting that one should never pull out the wee wee and check it for scabs whilst at the table.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Terribly sorry, Pocket,

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Not at all, I'm sure!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The South Park Classics study. The British Person resumes narrating

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: And so Pip spent the next several months learning how to be a gentleman. He was schooled in several languages. He was taught fencing and marksmanship, and he was shown how to dance and eat box. And after it all, after WEEKS and weeks of intense schooling, Pip was finally a full-fledged gentleman. Proud of himself, Pip decided to pay Ms. Havesham a visit, to thank her for her generosity, and to see if he was indeed, now, good enough for Estella.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Havesham Estate, exterior, then interior, at the dining room.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Good evening, Ms. Havesham.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Come closer, Pip.  My, you're quite the gentleman now, aren't you?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Thanks to you.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Perhaps. Estella's been off to school as well.  She's become quite the lady. Would you like to see a picture of her?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, my! She is even prettier than before.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Ohoh, you love her, don't you, Pip?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I don't know. I mean, I think about her every day.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Do you know what love is, Pip? It is blind devotion, unquestioning self-humiliation, utter submission, trust and belief against yourself and against the whole world, giving up your whole heart and soul to snip it.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Righto.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Love her, Pip. I developed her into what she is so that she might... be loved.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes, but... where will I find her?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: There's a dance at the Palace tomorrow night. Estella will be there. Go and seek her out. And love her. Love her!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Thank you, Ms. Havesham! For everything! I'm the happiest boy in the land!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: And if she warms to you, love her; she tears your heart into pieces. And as you get older it will tear deeper. Lover her.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The South Park Classics study. The British Person resumes narrating

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes. Our young Pip had come a long way. From the apprentice of a blacksmith to a fine young gentleman of great expectations. And now he was to finally see his beloved Estella again at a Grand Ball held by the King of England, Tony Blair. It was here that Pip would finally and formally ask Estella to be his girlfriend. And all would be right with the world.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Grand Ballroom at the Palace, evening. Tony Blair and wife descend the Grand Staircase as dozens of couples dance before them. The camera then pans across the scene and stops on Estella. Pip comes in from the side

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Hello, Estella.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Pip.  My goodness, how you've changed!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes. I've become a gentleman. May I?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I suppose.  So how is it that you've learned to dress and dance?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, I was sent to be schooled in London.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Iiii see, and you no longer live with the blacksmith?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh. I see Joe once in a while. But I don't have much in common with him anymore, now that I'm a gentleman and all.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Naturally.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: It is wonderful to see you again, Estella.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Is it? Why?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Because I believe I'm in love with you.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Pip, you must know that I have no heart.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I think you do.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, I have a heart to be shot or stabbed in, no doubt, and if it cease to beat I should cease to be, but  you know what I mean. I have no softness there, no sympathy, sentiment.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I see past that, Estella. I see a little girl who wants to be warm and kind.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Hey, Estella, let's get out of here.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Alright, Steve. Just one moment.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Who...? Who is that?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I see, and you... fancy this Steve fellow?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Boyfriend??

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: What's the matter, Pip?!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I don't understand! I did everything right! I stopped being a poor commoner! I even blew off my lovin' Joe!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: It's... it's... the way it goes sometimes, Pip.  He's... seventeen and has a car. I'm... I'm... very  I'm  leaving.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Havesham Estate, outside, a stormy night. Pip reaches the Havesham estate and enters the front gates. He heads into the house, up the spiral staircase, and into the dining room.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Ms. Havesham! You have to talk to Estella! She's going out with a-

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well well well, if it isn't Mr. Pip.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Ms. Havesham! But um...

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Don't they make a handsome couple, Pip? Look at the way he holds her hand.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: But I don't understand.  You sent me away to become a gentleman so that I could be with Estalla.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Things aren't always as they seem, Pip. Oh, what's the matter? Did she... break your heart?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: ...Well, I suppose that if you set out to break my heart, you did a very good job of it. Because it certainly does hurt.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes. Tell me about the pain.  Tell me about the crushing and the prickly things.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: It's... a-as if... sssomeone has a hold of my heart and isss  squeezing it very tightly.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Is your heart broken as well? Tell me all about it.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Wuh-hy? Well, that's simple. Because I need the tears of broken-hearted men to use in my Genesis device.  You see, my foolish child, I'm growing very old. But tonight I will fuse my soul into Estella's once and for all. And then I can go on breaking men's hearts for another generation.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: What the hell??

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Estella, prepare yourself for the Genesis platform.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh no, you don't! You're my girl! And I'm not lettin' you walk out on me! What the?!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: And as for you, Pip, my robot monkeys should take care of you!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The blacksmith's house, day. A shadow appears at Pip's door and falls on him. He awakens and looks at the source of the shadow

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Pip? Pip, old chap?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Joe?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: That's right. You're safe and warm now.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Joe found you lying face down in the street, Mr. Pip, You were in such a state. You've been unconscious here for nearly three hours.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Ms Havesham! She has all the men who have had their hearts broken by Estella trapped in her house!  Oh, why would she have wasted all that time sending me to school and making me into a gentleman?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, about that, Pip: There's another person who wants to see you.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Allo, Pip. You remember me?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I'll rip off your arms and shove 'em up your arse!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Why, you're the escaped convict I helped a long time ago.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes. After you helped me I moved to Wales and made somethin' o' myself. If it weren't for you, I'd have never become a millionaire.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: 'E's the one that sent you to London, Pip! 'E's the one who sent you off to be a gentleman!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: You? But why?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Because back then you treated me like any other person. You're weren't a snob and you helped me as you would a rich man.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, dear. All this time I thought it was Ms. Havesham. She totally let me believe it.

text: I tried to tell you, Pip. She's a vengeful, spiteful woman.who wanted nothing more than to see you hurt along with the rest of the male sex.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, I've certainly learned a lot. That being a gentleman doesn't mean learning to dance, or proper table manners. It means being a gentle man. Gentle to everyone.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Righto. Pip. Righto.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: And now I suppose there's only one thing left to do.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: What's that, Pip.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yeah!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The South Park Classics study. The British Person resumes narrating

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: And now we come to the final act of the Dickens classic tale, inwhich the stage is set for an epic showdown. Ms. Havesham's robot monkeys prove a formidable foe, but Pip is not about to let Estella's soul be forever consumed by the Genesis device. And now the thrilling conclusion of Great Expectations!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Havesham Estate, outside, a stormy night. In the dining room Ms. Havesham prepares Estella for the Genesis device

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Are you ready, Estella? Are you ready to complete the cycle?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS

text: Yes. Cry away, males.  Once your tears have collected into the Genesis device, the fusion of Estella and me will be complete.

text: It begins.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Come, Estella! You can't want to be part of this.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: It is... what I was raised for.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: AAAAAAA!!!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Hello, gentlemen. Oh, whatever you do, please do not cry. Havesham's device fuels itself on your tears, I'm afraid.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: How are we not to cry. Our hearts have been broken, our lives ruined, and now we are set to die!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes, but just thnk about... panda bears! Oh, they're so cuddly and sweet, panda bears are.  What silly little noses they have!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Panda bears make me sad. They're almost extinct.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, right, right, let's not think about panda bears, then. Let's think about ...swimming! Oh, what jolly fun swimming is, with a splishy-splash and a hold-your-breath dive.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Get out of that chair, you old cow!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Estella! Listen to me! You are a wonderful girl, with a kind heart.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I told you, Pip. I have no heart

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: But you do! And I shall prove it to you once and for all!  Look at this adorable little bunny.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh my. 'E's very cute.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: You see that? A heartless person wouldn't care at all about this bunny. They'd just as soon break its neck.  ...Oh. But look at this bunny.  There. You see that? You have too big a heart to kill two baby bunnies.  ...Right.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh what fun it is to collect stamps! Lick the backs, put them into books all neat and tidy with those smashing little pictures and bright colors.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: My father died in a stamp-collecting accident.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Right, let's not talk about stamp-collecting, then. Let's talk about...

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Ice-skating!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh what fun ice-skating is!  Who can catch me? Who can catch the ice-skating king? That's me.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oy can't figh' 'em off no moh!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Nine. Nine baby bunnies. A person with a heart could never kill nine baby bunnies. So you do have too big a heart to- Ten baby bunnies!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: ...There's too many of them!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Please, sirs, you must not cry!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: We can't help it! You're bawlin' us to tears!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Philip, it's too late!!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Twenty-six baby bunnies

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I don't want to. I don't see the point in this.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: What?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: I don't want to kill any more of them.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: There! You see?! You do have a heart!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: You think so? Let me see it  Maybe I can kill it.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: No no, I'm sure of it. You have a heart! You've bought your own life! Come with me now!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yessss!  Noooo!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Ooooo, top smart, Pip!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: You did it, Pip!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The Havesham Estate, outside, a stormy night. Joe, Pip, Pocket, the nine males, and Estella leave the house as flames spread from the dining room to other rooms and onto the yard. The party moves towards the gate, then turns back to watch the burning house

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Well, I guess Old Ms. Havesham won't be takin' any revenge on any more blokes, ey?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes. her poor miserable life is finally over.

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: You're released from her now, Estella! Now we can begin our life together!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Yes! Yes, my small-testicled love!

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: Oh, I'm so glad everything has worked out.  Where are all my little bunnies that you borrowed then, Pip?

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: The South Park Classics study. The British Person finishes narrating

title: GREAT EXPECTATIONS
text: And they all lived happily ever after. Except for Pocket, who died of hepatitis B.  So ends Charles Dickens' Great Expectaton.We hope you now have a deeper appreciation for Pip, and indeed,  all masterpieces of literature like this one.  Until next time, I'm a British person. Good night.
